title: Angular momentum conservation - claim about angula

content.question: In a second experimental trial, the wheel is initially rotating counterclockwise. A piece of clay that has the same mass as the wheel is traveling directly to the right at a speed of <math alttext="12 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>12</mtext><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mstyle></math>, colliding with, and sticking to, the top of the outer rim of the wheel. Which of the following claims about the motion of the clay-wheel system is correct, and has correct reasoning to support that claim?

choices.label: The system is not rotating after the collision because the clay and wheel have the same mass.
The system is not rotating after the collision because the initial angular momenta of the clay and wheel are in opposite directions.
The rotation of the system after the collision cannot be determined because the initial angular velocity of the wheel is unknown.
The rotation of the system after the collision cannot be determined because translational motion and rotational motion are independent motions.

content.answer: The rotation of the system after the collision cannot be determined because the initial angular velocity of the wheel is unknown.

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
